reviewText: Oh, those childhood memories.  Those very inaccurate history lessons, very bad puns, and cheezy animation.  No, I'm not talking about "South Park."  I'm referring to those Jay Ward shorts in the Rocky and Bullwinkle Show.  Still, this IS funny stuff.  Well worth owning.  Anyone interested in animation or those wacky 60s and 70s should make this required viewing.  The jokes are a little stale now, but were they ever that fresh anyway.  Who cares!!! It's Mr. Peabody and his boy Sherman.  Sit (way)back and enjoy.

The Peabody & Sherman shorts just might get kids interested in learning history. No, the cartoons aren't terribly accurate, certainly aren't culturally sensitive, and are filled with silly puns, but they are still clean, funny, and watchable decades after their release. If they spark a young girl or boy's interest in the past, then bravo.
Good throw-back entertainment.  Remember these as a kid from the Rocky & Bullwinkle show.  Not super halirous, but good enough.....especially when compared to modern cartoons.

Though the animation is dated, the humor transcends it's time and makes the original episodes of "Mr. Peabody & Sherman" more worth watching than recent modern attempts to bring them back to audiences. If you want to travel through time with these two, it's worth the trip to travel back to their original show instead!

and voices and of course the music for making the series a classic in every good sense of the word.

I loved the Rocky & Bullwinkle show. Mr. Peabody & Sherman was, and still is, delightful. As a kid, my mother leveraged this show as an incentive for me to get my chores done. No Chores (or home-work, or piano practice), then no Peabody & Sherman.
Now that I'm older, I am amazed at the highly intellectual and satirical writing of the Rocky & Bullwinkle episodes. I had fun with it in my youth and have even more fun with it now. Lots of good, clean, un-offensive fun.

The button-down humor of the 1960 original gets canned in favor of a sentimental and silly script further diluted with a love interest for Sherman. Rent it if you must, but the purchased Blu-Ray is more likely to gather dust than get worn out by the kids. Kids won't get the one or two cool puns, teens won't really care one way or the other... and us old boomers will simply be bored. Not in any way an awful film, but most certainly a forgettable one.

It would be a shame if folks only saw the full length movie and based their impression of Mr. Peabody and Sherman off that weak poorly done shadow of what the original series brought to bare.  Sometimes remakes work - and sometimes they don't...the original series work well enough

The words "smart" and "cartoon" don't often fit together. Unless Jay Ward is involved. Mr. Peabody's adventures in time (with his adopted boy, Sherman) were a popular feature of Ward's "Rocky and Bullwinkle" show. These shorts gleefully butcher everything you ever learned about history, lampooning great discoveries and achievements from ancient Greece into the 19th century. Peabody's genius always saves the day, while the dimwitted Sherman sets up the inevitable bad pun to cap off the episode. If you enjoyed the recent movie, you'll love the material that inspired it.

I recently took my two young grandsons to see the new movie of the same name.  Of course, they never had their dad wake them up in Saturday morning (c. 1960) to watch Rocky and Bullwinkle.  Everyone else in our house wanted to sleep in but Dad knew I would be only too glad to drag my blanket and pillow and sit on the floor next to his chair to watch cartoons every Saturday.  Rocky and Bullwinkle were big favorites of his.  Anyway, the series still works and is still fun to watch.  A perfect combination of both silly and sophisticated jokes, with some sweetness thrown in.  Fun for kids and adults alike, at least I hope so.  Today's kids are pretty used to c.g. effects and may find this boring.  They might actually have to pay attention to the dialogue!
Good humor doesn't age.  Wish some some of it was in the newer TV shows. Will look for more only wish there was more Rocky and Bulwinkle, too.
At the age of 70, it's wonderful to watch this delightful series of programs and recapture my childhood.  The characters have lost nothing in the passing of the years.

Loved watching the associated shows of Rocky & Bullwinkle as a kid, now re-watching with my kids brings back great memories with the added knowledge of adult humor that was added. This cartoon could be educational by reinforcing events in history in a funny way. However today's kids are used to watching cartoons with a bit more drama.  So while the humor and history in this is going to be appreciated by a 7yr or up, the animation style will appeal more to a 4-5 yr old.

The funny thing is that I didn't realize when I was a kid how crudely some of the characters are drawn, but that downtick does not affect my enjoyment.

(I assume the "Wayback Machine" that shows how web pages used to look years ago got its name from Mr. Peabody's invention.)

I especially love the puns at the end of each historical vignette, for example,

the sea explorer who was first to travel around the world being such a good poker player that he won 265 games in a row, all with the same type of hand. It's in the history books, the STRAIGHTS OF MAGELLAN.

or the famous author who got put in jail, he was BARRED IN AVON, but history changed it to BARD OF AVON.

I hope when I get done with the BEST OF, that I will find other examples. I'm watching it in small pieces so my enjoyment can stretch.

Or maybe I'll have to borrow the Wayback Machine to bring more episodes back from the past.

Oh, God. I've just let everybody know how old I am! Once upon a time, when the world made sense(at least to me) there was a cartoon called Rockey and Friends, featuring Rocket(hence Rocky) J. Squirrell and his best friend, Bullwinkle T. Moose. They  had an arch enemy named Boris Badenov and his girlfriend, Natasha. You younger pups may have seen an extremely forgettable movie featuring them. It was so bad and forgettable that, thankfully, I forgot the name of the movie. Rocky's friends included Dudley Doright of the Royal Canadian Mounties and his girlfriend Nell, Aesop's fables, Fractured Fairy Tales and our above featured duo, Mr. Peabody & Sherman. Mr. Peabody was obviously a dog, albeit a genius, who had adopted a young boy named Sherman from an orphange. As he put it, "If every boy should have a dog, it was only logical that every dog should have a boy." Mr. Peabody had invented the Wayback Machine which allowed he and Sherman to enter a date, step into the Wayback Machine, and immediately be transported back in time to that date. These trips usually came about because Sherman was a bright and inquisitive boy and wanted to know the story behind whatever had occured on that date. Nine times out of nine, Mr. Peabody had to intervene because somone was about to do something stupid, which would have altered what we now know was the course of history as it was supposed to have happened. At the end of every story, when Mr. Peabody had set the course of history straight, he offered up to Sherman an excellent lesson punctuated by an equally excellent pun. The show was great for many reasons, not the least of which was it taught kids history. The history may have been somewhat skewed in the telling but, in the end, it made history interesting for kids and also taught them the meaning of satire! You'll notice that Amazon also offers all of the affiliated Rocky shows in their catalog. If you enjoy this series, do yourself a favor and look up the Pogo series. Pogo was a possum in the swamps of the Okeefenokee and featured one of the most intriguing set of characters you will ever meet.  There was Howlan Owl, Albert the Alligator, Churchy LaFemme(get it?) the turtle, 'Lil Pup Dog, and many others. The strip was written by Walt Kelly, one of the greatest cartoonists and philosophers who ever lived. He was one of the first major cartoonists to lampoon public politicians, from George Wallace, J. Edgar Hoover, Spiro Agnew, Tricky Dick Nixon, and a host of others. He was fearless in his visual portrayals of them and his unabashed opinion of the cultural times. You will not only enjoy all of the shenanigans of the denizens of the swamp, but it's also a real hoot to try to recognize all the public figures. He took on the KKK, whom he referred to as the Kluck Klams, and no nut fringe group or individual was left unscathed. I know I say it a lot but, THANK YOU AMAZON for making these incredibly historical and important glimpses into another time available to us. I hope you enjoy all of these collections and take great personal pride that you can actually understand the difference between them and the garbage that our children watch today that are passed off as cartoons. I'm sorry, I forgot that what our kids watch today really ARE cartoons aimed at "the great unwashed" who wouldn't be able to comprehend the afore mentioned works of art. I wish I could take credit for the  term "the great unwashed", but I can't remember where I heard it, So instead of suing me for plagerism, take gratification in the fact that I liked it enough to steal it! I'll leave plagerism to a certain current politician(we all KNOW who you are!) At least, he doesn't mangle the language like another of his cohorts, W, did. THANKS- Tim Drain. You're all welcome to email me at william.t.drain@gmail.com if you like. I must caution you that I'm somewhat crazy, but you probably already know that.

Just like the Simpsons (Homer J. Simpson, Bart J. Simpson, etc.), the Bullwinkle charters have the middle initial of J., named after the founder, Jay Ward. An homage to Bullwinkle (including Mr. Peabody), The Simpsons and other adult-humor cartoons were heavily influenced directly or indirectly by Ward Productions. Mr. Peabody is probably the most subtle of the Ward cartoons. So this is a gem. I hope the upcoming movie release isn't a disastrous attempt to capitalize on something incredible, yet kitschy.

Before there was Dr. Who, before Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure,  there was the Rocky and Bullwinkle show, with many fast paced fractured tales of history and fairy tales.
As a regular staple of cartoon viewing in the early 1960s, Jay Ward's production stood out from the others with quick, sly wit, bad puns and fast pace.

This collection is a wonderful example of the style of his animation, starting from the very first Mr. Peabody and Sherman cartoon installment, setting up the series and explaining
just who they are and why they are together.  Bet you never heard that tale, did you?

This volume, billed "The BEST of Mr. Peabody and Sherman Volume 1" contains 15 of the roughly five minute features, with luminaries like, Napolean, Cleopatra, Ben Franklin, and others.  The puns come thick and fast, but the last bad pun for the closer is guaranteed to be a groaner.

This is a must see for the younger generation, to see what their parents and grandparents grew up on, long before Bart and Homer Simspson tried to corner the market on smart ass comments.

A reasonable value on it's own, an extra feature of the Bullwinkle live puppet intros that were featured during the first season are included.

Though this DVD doesn't show anything more than the basic Mr. Peabody and Sherman, it is a good item to have or share.  Perhaps another DVD that contains a sample complete show might give more of the overall flavor, but this isn't bad.

My kids were appalled, but sat through the entire DVD with mom and dad and we laughed again at the bad puns and simple animation. Don't miss this opportunity to share the laughs.

outstanding entertainment for all ages from a time when cartoons did not always indoctrinate, but could be educational as well as entertaining. For those of us old enough to remember, it's a great trip down memory lane. For those younger, it's a fun way to learn about history.
The best of Mr. Peabody & Sherman is a great dvd to buy. I enjoyed it alot. It is just as I remember watching when I was a Kid. The Best of Mr. Peabody & Sherman, Vol. 1

With Johnny Depp scheduled to play Mr. Peabody, you may wish to check out the source material. There are a few references to period happenings and persons, but they still hold up as good old-fashioned fun.

Don't you all find it odd and interesting that , the DOG, Mr . Peabody is highly intelligent and an intellectual. ALL TV dogs, thanks to hanna-barbera are DUMB, STUPID, or COWARDS. (Scooby-Doo). It is refreshing to see a cartoon with SOME educational value and done with good wit.  I don't think there has been another SMART canine. The closest
being BRIAN on Family Guy. But compared to peabody, Brian is a loser lol. Long Live Peabody!

Buy this DVD for your fourth through eighth grader and watch it with them.  They'll get a history lesson with each episode and you can laugh together at the humor of Jay Ward (Rocky & Bullwinkle, Fractured Fairytales, Dudley Dooright, Boris & Natasha, et al).  Mr. Peabody adopts a boy, Sherman, and invents the WABAC (pronounced way back) machine to entertain and educate his young charge.  You can do the same for your young charges with this DVD.

As a kid, I remember watching the fractured fairy tales along with the Mr. Peabody & Sherman show, which was one of my favorites.  The DVD "Best Of Vol. 1" has many of the classics and is still entertaining to watch.  Seller A+ with quick delivery
Rocky & Bullwinkle was a favorite growing up. Mr. Peabody & his pet boy Sherman was my favorite from the series along with fractured fairy tales. Seller A+.Quick delivery.

This delightful, smartly written cartoon is not just funny, it's a great way to get kids into history.  Mr. Peabody's complete self-confidence never wavered and was completely believable.  His boy, Sherman, was delightfully inquisitive on their adventures.  I watched this religiously as a kid, and was thrilled to find it on DVD to give to my history-major daughter.  It's a great break from the mundane, and reminds us that history is still relevant.

Are you kidding me? Mr. Peabody and Sherman. Really not much to say. If you know it than you love it even if the animation isn't so great. It has the original Bullwinkle Puppet intros in the special features, a pretty nifty looking dvd case, alot of episodes. Not much more to say. These cartoons are hard to find and they don't really show them on tv anymore.

Kids and adults will love these cartoons. I loved them as a kid but now I can appreciate some of the underlying adult humor. My neices like the funny cartoons and how they go back in time to give history lessons.

These cartoons, included with the Rocky and Bulwinkle show are just the best, funniest cartoon ever on tv and even at my age I still laugh at them. Glad I made the purchase of the DVDs. And I recommend buying them via Amazon, as the price is surely the best you will find.

I purchesed this dvd for my 9yr old son who we nicknamed Sherman because of the bond he has with his grandfathers dog.  He watched the dvd and loved every minute of it and frankly so did I.  It brought back memories of when i was younger watching and made me feel good when i was that my son "Sherman" enjoyed the cartoon just as much as i did.
We used to watch these all the time as a kid, and it's so fun to see them again!
These are great for those who don't have a great imagination.  This is a great classic cartoon that I highly recommend to anyone and everyone.

**Updated 6/7/10** For those who have the season 1, 2, 3, 4 & 5 or "The Complete Bull" you will want to avoid this, but it is still fun in its own right The numbers are the sequence numbers for Mr. Peabody, not the episodes they appeared in. From season 1 Rocky & Bullwinkle & Friends - The Complete First Season 1 Benjamin Franklin (aka Introduction) Mr. Peabody goes out & gets a pet boy. From season 2 Rocky & Bullwinkle & Friends - The Complete Second Season 38 Pancho Villa 36 Christopher Columbus 47 Francisco Pisaro 50 William Shakespeare 55 Ferdinand Magellan From season 3 Rocky & Bullwinkle & Friends - The Complete Third Season 64 Ludwig Von Beethoven 65 Calamity Jane 68 Jules Verne 70 Lawrence of Arabia 76 Jim Bowie From season 4 Rocky & Bullwinkle & Friends: Season 4 (2pc) 78 Charge of the Light Brigade 85 Wellington at Waterloo 86 Florence Nightingale 91 Cleopatra (the final Mr. Peabody cartoon produced)

Some of the pun references are so old that they would not be understood today.  And of course some of the characterizations might now be considered insensitive and politically incorrect.  In spite of all that Peabody is a very witty and funny know-it-all.  I can watch this repeatedly and not get bored.

If you remember the Rocky and Bullwinkle clan then you'll remember Mr. Peabody and Sherman. Your kids will enjoy his somewhat skewed view of historical events just as we did. The Wayback Machine is working just as well as before! Older kids may not find it as fun, but still will enjoy looking at history at a different angle.
Love Mr Peabody.  I originally watched this series in B&W.  Ooh, that makes me sound old.  I loved it then and I love it still. I am looking forward to Vol 2.

I want to start off by saying that I am not a serious collector so my review will not be based on other products of this nature.  I simply bought the video to share with my children.  I wanted them to see what animation was like when I was little.  They couldn't believe we only watched cartoons on Saturday morning.  This was a great memory and we had a wonderful time watching Mr. Peabody and Sherman solve the historical mysteries.

I had purchased this for my husband for christmas, and the good thing about it is that not only did he love it, but it gives my children a chance to see really good cartoons for a change!

This one is a definate order for anyone who enjoys the good old cartoons!

Mr. Peabody is a TV talisman.  I always walk away from these cartoons feeling magically transformed and energized.

In the realm of vintage cartoons made on minimal budgets, Jay Ward rules!  Peabody & Sherman, along with Rocky & Bullwinkle, etc, were very much like sly, fast-talking radio plays staged by smartly stylized cartoon characters.  This DVD also contains rare Bullwinkle puppet segments that were used in the early broadcasts.  They too underline how WAY ahead of the curve Ward was in terms of getting sophisticated and sometimes subversive humor in under the radar.

By the way, Peabody's "boy" Sherman was voiced by a man in his 40's named Robert Tetley.  Amazing.
